"What is the firm doing to address the fact that the culture is dying and our reputation is deteriorating?" asks one woman. "Absolute silence followed," he writes. In fact the questioner asks about the "perception" that the culture is deteriorating, according to audio heard by the Guardian. There is a short pause before the Goldman execs answer with some banalities but hardly "absolute silence". According to Goldman, Smith's town hall hero is the same woman that only a few pages earlier Smith describes as a "vicious boss" nicknamed the "Black Widow" for her "penchant for trying to get colleagues fired". Unsurprisingly Goldman has its own harsh critique of Smith's account. An internal review of Goldman's emails found 99.7% of references to "muppets" were related to 2011's outing for the puppet characters in which Miss Piggy, Kermit and Co reunite to save their old theatre from a greedy oil tycoon. The bank also said it undertook peer review polls and said Smith's average rating of his colleagues was nine – the highest mark on their nine-point scale. "We thoroughly reviewed Greg's claims and found no evidence whatsoever to support them," said Jake Siewert, Goldman's corporate communications chief. "We were hampered by the fact that there was little that was specific. We found no evidence that he raised concerns while at the bank but he did express concerns about his career." For Cohan the problem with Smith's book is that it is a morality tale that doesn't work: "He spent 12 years taking their money and suddenly the scales fall from his eyes?" According to Cohan Goldman has been rife with conflicts of interest throughout its 143-year history. "This is not a charitable institution," he said. He said it was "hypocritical" of Smith to take Goldman's salary, complain about his bonus and then turn around and kick his former employer. "Wall Street has huge problems and he is exhibit A," said Cohan.
fields.headline: Why I Left Goldman Sachs author is biggest 'muppet' say reviewers
fields.trailText: Greg Smith's book is remarkably short on details – and some of those it does contain have been challenged

webTitle: Eurozone crisis live: Hollande and Merkel both offer Ireland hope

fields.standfirst:
• Hollande: I back more help for Ireland
• Merkel: Ireland is a 'special case'
• Germany denies threatening to cancel next summit in row with UK
• Cameron stands firm over EU budget
• Europe's debt pile hits new record
fields.body:
5.22pm BST

CLOSING SUMMARY

Looks like events are over for the day, so I'm going to shut up shop till the morning.

Here's a closing summary of the main developments:

• Ireland has won support from the eurozone's two most powerful leaders over its calls for a new deal on its legacy banking debts. French president François Hollande said he believes Irish banks should be retrospectively recapitalised (see 15.08 onwards). The comments came hours after Dublin and Berlin issued a joint statement saying Ireland deserves 'special treatment' (see 8.12am onwards)

• Greece has seen political ructions. Finance minister Yiannis Stournaras warned that Athens risks running out of money (see 16.31) while the expulsion of a government MP showed rising tensions over its austerity package (see 12.46)

• David Cameron has pledged not to allow the EU budget to rise above inflation. The UK prime minister told parliament he was still prepared to veto a budget deal, despite German concern (see 15.58 onwards)

However both sides denied a report that Angela Merkel might cancel next month's EU summit rather than risk Cameron red-carding the budget (see 11.14 for Berlin's comments and 12.19 for the Downing Street briefing).

• Eurozone and EU government debts hit a record high. Data for 2011 also showed that the overall budget deficit of the euro area and the EU fell last year, but 17 countries have deficits above 3%. (See 10.14 onwards)

See you again tomorrow. Thanks (as ever), and goodnight!

5.18pm BST

CYPRUS CALLING TROIKA BACK

Some late news out of Nicosia – Cyprus is planning to contact its Troika of lenders tonight and invite them back to the island for "final negotiations" on its aid deal (that's via Reuters).

4.52pm BST

MARKETS ROUND-UP

Europe's stock markets have closed, with the main indices mostly lower.

Traders say a disappointing set of financial results from Caterpillar have eaten into confidence.

FTSE 100: down 13 points at 5882, - 0.2%

German DAX: down 58 points at 7322, -0.79%

French CAC: down 22 points at 3481, -0.65%

Spanish IBEX: down 36 points at 7877, - 0.46%

Italian FTSE MIB: up 4 points at 15866, + 0.03%

In the debt markets, the yield on Spanish 10-year government bonds has been creeping higher through the afternoon, now up 14 basis points at 5.521%.

That reflects uncertainty over when Spain might end the suspense and apply for a bailout. Having survived the weekend's regional elections (see 13.52), Mariano Rajoy might drag the drama out a little longer....

Updated at 4.59pm BST

4.31pm BST

Greek finance minister: time is running out....

Over in Athens alarming statements have been made this afternoon by the country's ever-optimistic finance minister.

Our correspondent Helena Smith reports:

The Greek finance minister Yiannis Stournaras did not mince his words addressing the Greek parliament this afternoon.

Stournaras said that If Greece failed to take receipt of its next rescue loans, "people would go hungry," he said, adding:

The cost for the country will be boundless if we don't get the €31.5bn installment... If we don't get the loan people will go hungry.

Stournaras also asked, rhetorically, if MPs think "the Europeans are bluffing" over their demands for new cuts, adding:

Time is running out. If we want to get the installment before state funds at our disposal are exhausted we must move very quickly.

Updated at 4.31pm BST

4.27pm BST

CAMERON: WE DON'T ACCEPT INCREASE IN EU BUDGET SPENDING

Back to Westminster, where David Cameron has repeated that he will not accept a real-terms increase in the EU budget when leaders meet next month.

The PM said:

I'm happy to talk, but not happy to spend a lot of money.

Cameron added that there is no need to reach a deal on the EU budget in November. However long the issue rumbles on, though, his position won't change....

Cameron also agreed that eurozone banking union will lead towards full political and fiscal union in time, as German taxpayers helping Greek banks or French taxpayers supporting Spanish ones are "deeply political issues".

4.16pm BST

News from Helsinki -- Finnish prime minister Jyrki Katainen was
unhurt after a man approached him with a knife on Monday.

According to Finland's Helsingin Sanomat newspaper, the man was taken into custody in handcuffs after getting within "a few feet" of Katainen. There are no reports of injuries.

Katainen was campaigning in Turku, in Western Finland.

The full story can be seen on Helsingin Sanomat's website (in Finnish).

Updated at 4.18pm BST

4.07pm BST

Cameron gives muted cheer to EU's Peace Prize

David Cameron was just asked whether he supports the decision to award the Nobe Peace Prize to the European Union.

In response, the UK PM said

There is a case that the institutions which were put into place after the second world war, and I'd include NATO as well as the European Union, have helped us to settle differences round table and not on the battlefields of Flanders.

Cameron also confirmed that he won't be showing up in Oslo to collect the prize, and seemed disappointed that the idea of 27 young people acting as Prize-bearers (which he had argued for) had not found favour.

Updated at 4.07pm BST

4.01pm BST

One of David Cameron's own MPs, Douglas Carswell, has blasted the government for agreeing Europe's move towards banking union at last week's summit.

3.58pm BST

David Cameron updates MPs on EU summit

Over in parliament, David Cameron is updating MPs on the events at last week' EU council summit.

Cameron reiterated that he wants some powers repatriated from Brussels, but does not want the UK to quit the European Union.

I don't support the Status Quo, but nor do I believe exit is the answer.

Cameron also confirmed that he wants the next EU budget to be capped with an inflation-only increase

We need to maximise our leverage on that specific issue

Several MPs have asked about the plans for a eurozone banking union, with Conservative MP Bernard Jenkins claiming it is the "worst of all possible worlds" for the UK.

Cameron disagrees, explaining:

The proposals for banking union need to be agreed by unanimity - that is an important safeguard for Britain.

But it would not be in Britain's interest to stop the eurozone putting into place something that is necessary for its future.

Cameron added that banking union is needed to bring down Spanish and Italian bond yields.

3.26pm BST

HOLLANDE ARGUES FOR RETROSPECTIVE RECAPITALISATION

Francois Hollande went on to tell the press conference in Paris that he would support a "retroactive recapitalisation" of Irish banks.

And here's the key quote from Hollande:

I said Ireland was a special case and should be treated as such.

Hollande also said that France "will be supportive" if Spain applies for a bailout.

The argument for retrospectively putting new capital into Irish banks is that its bailout came before Europe had agreed its new bailout mechanisms - so Ireland arguably got an unfair deal.

Tony Connelly of RTE is in Paris, and reports:

3.08pm BST

HOLLANDE OFFERS IRELAND SUPPORT

Irish Taoiseach Enda Kenny has arrived in Paris for his meeting with president Francois Hollande (see 10.45am for more details)

And Hollande has been quick to offer Kenny his support, saying that he agrees that Ireland is a special case when it comes to dealing with legacy of its bad banking debts.

More to follow...

Updated at 3.17pm BST

2.43pm BST

Sterling hits four-month low against the euro

The pound hit another four-month low against the euro today, after dropping around 0.3 of a eurocent to €1.2266.

Sterling has been on a steady slide against the euro since late July, when it came close to hitting €1.2900. It began falling after Mario Draghi, ECB president, made his famous speech that 'the euro was irreversible'.

Christopher Vecchio, currency analyst at DailyFX, said the euro had been boosted today by the Spanish elections:

The election results mean that Spain will not see Prime Minister Rajoy leave office anytime soon.

This means that Spain’s future in the Euro is secure (at least the near-term horizon is less uncertain, if only marginally).

2.29pm BST

Research Group: Spain should apply for bailout now

Mariano Rajoy should seize the moment and apply for financial aid immediately now that regional elections are over, argues a research body with close links to Spain's business leaders.

Jose Luis Feito, chairman of Instituto de Estudios Economicos, said that Rajoy's victory in Galicia (see 13.52) should be the catalyst for a bailout request.

Feito said (via Bloomberg):

Spain should accept conditions set by the European Central Bank and other European authorities and the sooner the better...

It’s very difficult to impose substantial cuts in public services that hit living standards, but the longer we wait, the more difficult and drastic it’ll be.

Last weekend's election results may have bought Rajoy some time. However there are more elections due in a few weeks, which could bolster political parties seeking independence.

As Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research points out:

The next bid regional election takes place on November 25th in Catalonia where various parties are pushing for more autonomy or even independence. Think of it like Scotland but with a much better football team…

He may have a point...

1.52pm BST

Markets calm after Spanish elections

In the City, a calm morning of trading has left the main indices little changed - with the FTSE 100 down just 3 points at 5892, and the German DAX 0.3% lower at 7358.

No major drama in the debt markets either, with Spain's 10-year bond yields creeping a little higher to 5.43% this morning.

That follows two Spanish regional elections last weekend, which were seen as a possible vote of confidence in the country's austerity prrogramme.

The governing People's Party won in Galicia, home state of Mariano Rajoy, Spain's prime minister.

However there was also a surge of support for pro-independence candidates in the Basque region, as reported here: Pro-independence parties win Basque country elections in Spain.

In short, the election results seen unlikely to trigger the much-awaited aid request from Madrid.

As Rebecca O'Keeffe, Head of Investment at Interactive Investor, comments:

Rajoy enjoyed a solid victory in regional elections in Galicia, offering support for his current austerity policies, and giving him time to decide when to request a bailout from the EU.

Updated at 2.03pm BST

1.03pm BST

Greek 2011 deficit higher than thought

This morning's data on eurozone government debt (see 10.14am onwards) also had bad news for Greece, Helena Smith points out.

Greece's deficit for 2011 was estimated at 9.4%, up from an earlier forecast of 9.1%. Its debt pile (following March's huge bond swap) was also calculated at €365bn or 170.6% of GDP up from 165.3%. 

Helena explains:

The figures are further proof that all hopes of reaching the debt-to- GDP ratio of 120% by 2020 are conclusively over.

Thus the behind-the-scenes battles between the EU and the IMF over how to bring Greece closer to debt sustainability (as our own Ian Traynor wrote back on 12 October)

Helena adds:

Prime minister Antonis Samaras told reporters in Brussels last week that he had taken a “defensive position” over how the debt load could be made sustainable.

12.46pm BST

Over to Athens again, where our correspondent Helena Smith says the expulsion this morning of a governing New Democracy party MP (see 9.34am) has highlighted the vehemence of the opposition to imposing yet more austerity.

With only weeks to go before parliament votes on austerity measures worth €13.5bn – the biggest package of budget cuts since the debt crisis erupted in Athens three years ago – prime minister Antonis Samaras is not taking any chances. Opposition over the cuts is fierce with members of all three parties in his fragile coalition refusing to endorse measures that, once again, will hit pensioners and low-income Greeks hardest.

By expelling Nikos Stavrogiannis, one of his own MPs, the conservative leader wanted to send a clear message “that there can be no good or bad politicians who do or don’t support the package,” reported the state-run news network, NET.

Samaras's office has also announced that the prime minister will meet his junior coalition partners on Tuesday. Tensions are clearly on the rise, with Syriza leader Alexis Tsipras announcing that “these should be the first measures that are not passed.” and claiming the coalition “is hanging by a thread.”

The spending cuts, which will be spread over two years, have to be voted through Athens’ 300-seat House by November 12 when euro zone finance ministers meet to decide whether Greece has qualified for its next cash disbursement – worth €31.5bn. Alarmingly, that's only 4 days before Greece runs out of cash.

As on insider told Helena:

Once more we are in a race against time if the country is to avoid bankruptcy.

However, Syriza has also debunked rumours that the party would trigger a snap poll by getting its deputies to resign en masse from parliament. Helena explains:

“Our tactic is to have fresh elections and I would say they are close,” Panos Skourletis told me this morning. “But that doesn’t mean it is a demand for elections here and now,” he said, adding that it was unlikely a new poll would be held before the end of the year.

Updated at 1.06pm BST

12.19pm BST

UK STICKING TO ITS GUNS ON EU BUDGET

The UK government has told reporters in Westminster that Germany has not threatened to cancel next month's summit (at least, not to them, anyway)

My colleague Andrew Sparrow was at the Number 10 briefing, and reports that the government also reiterated its opposition to an above-inflation increase. He writes:

We do not see the need for an increase in spending above the rate of inflation," the spokesman said. He would not say what measure of inflation Cameron would use to judge any proposed budget increase. And he said Number 10 had not been told by the Germans that Angela Merkel would cancel next month's EU summit if Cameron was determined to veto the proposed budget, as the Financial Times reports today (paywall).

The full briefing is live on Andrew's Politics Live blog.

So could the FT have got it wrong? Seems unlikely.....

...and Channel 4's Faisal Islam agrees:

12.02pm BST

BUNDESBANK IN NEW MONETARY POLICY ALERT

The Bundesbank warned this morning that Europe's crisis measures are increasing the risks to eurozone taxpapers.

In its monthly report, Germany's central bank once again voiced its concerns over policies such as the European Central Bank's offer of "unlimited bond-buying' for a country which seeks help.

Here's the key quote:

The more effectively monetary policy supports the financial systems of the crisis countries with its measures, the more risks are transferred to the balance sheet of the euro system and ultimately redistributed among all taxpayers of member countries.

The crux of the Bundesbank's argument remains that monetary policy is now being used to stabilise the eurozone, which is really the job of fiscal policy.

The Bundesbank also predicted that the German economy could shrink during the last three months of 2012 as demand for exports falls, due to problems across the world economy.

It said:

While industrial orders from the euro zone have not fallen further after massively dropping in previous quarters, the expansion of demand from other countries has come to a standstill in the wake of a global economic slowdown.

Updated at 12.02pm BST

11.26am BST

UK FACES 'LONELY BATTLES' IN EUROPE

Neil Prothero, Eurozone analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit, warns that Britain faces some tough battles in Europe -- the spat over the EU budget is just one problem among many.

Prothero writes:

The UK's relations with the EU have always been complicated and prickly, but they are now entering uncharted territory as the policy agenda becomes increasingly dominated by politically sensitive issues setting the UK at odds with its EU partners.

The first of these is the seven-year framework for the EU budget, covering the period from 2014 to 2020. The European Commission wants the size of the EU budget to be increased, a proposal which is anathema to the British government at a time of fiscal austerity at home. The UK is not the only country opposed to a large increase in the EU budget. But few are likely to fight as hard or as long against an increase as the UK.

For his part, the British prime minister, David Cameron, is under enormous pressure from his own largely Eurosceptic Conservative Party to veto any budget deal that is inimical to British interests. Further struggles over banking union and efforts to repatriate key powers will follow, as pressures build on both sides of the Channel. Financial market pressures are forcing euro zone countries to contemplate deeper integration, while domestic political pressures are pushing the UK in the opposite direction.

The UK will therefore find itself fighting some lonely battles over the coming months.

Our Europe editor Ian Traynor warned a week ago that last week's EU summit would push Britain closer to the exits in this article: Europe prepares for another Franco-German tussle in Brussels.

EU policymakers may not want to push the UK out, but they won't jump through hoops to keep the country in, either.

Updated at 11.27am BST

11.14am BST

GERMANY DENIES SUMMIT ROW WITH BRITAIN

The German government has denied that it is threatening to cancel December's EU summit unless Britain caves in over the European Union's budget (see 8.25am)

Steffen Seibert, Angela Merkel's official spokesman, just told reporters in Berlin that the report (the front page splash of today's Financial Times) was wrong.

Seibert said:

It is not true. I categorically deny this report.

The German government has an interest in the success of this special summit in November and supports European Council President Herman van Rompuy in the goal to get an agreement on the long-term 2014-2020 budget.

Seibert also tried to calm talk that Britain's future in Europe was at risk, saying the UK is a "very valued member" of the EU.

But someone will have to change their position over the EU budget. As things stand, Merkel wants a smaller increase than the European Commission is proposing, while Cameron wants no increase at all...

10.45am BST

UPDATE FROM IRELAND

There isn't universal joy in Ireland today over the joint statement released by the Dublin and Berlin governments last night.

Henry McDonald, our correspondent in Dublin, reports that there is little rejoining on the opposition benches of the Dail (the Irish parliament) at Angela Merkel's show of support (see 8.12am for the details).

Henry writes:

Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams says today:

What is progress is when we get a write-down, when we get our money back.

The Louth TD told RTE's "Good Morning Ireland" radio show that:

The Government have borrowed €67bn from the troika - €64bn of that into banks, including some banks which are totally failed. The Taoiseach has yet to say that this debt is unsustainable.

Kenny meanwhile is in Paris today where the Taoiseach will meet Francois Hollande and also promote Irish food exports. The Republic exported €650 million euros worth of food to the EU last year. France remains one of Ireland's biggest markets with the French eating more Irish lamb and seafood that other Europeans.

The Taoiseach will join 18 Irish food companies and Bord Bia (the state body promoting Irish foodstuffs) at a world food fair in the French capital. 

Last night's telephone chat with the German Chancellor and today's trip to Paris will be welcome relief for Kenny after he and his government faced a string of torrid headlines at the weekend. Most of the Irish Sundays claimed the Germans had thrown Kenny under a car by indicating there would be no bank debt deal for Ireland from the new European Monetary System. 

Over the last 24 hours however the tone of Dublin newspaper coverage has started to change with the Irish Independent reported today that "Merkel rides to Enda's aid..." HMcD

(check out 8.43am for pictures of two Irish front pages).

Updated at 10.58am BST

10.33am BST

17 EU Members have 'excessive' deficits

The government debt figures released by Eurostat this morning (see 10.14) also show that 17 of the 25 members of the EU have deficits above 3% (the maximum level 'permitted' under EU laws).

They are:

• Ireland (-13.4%), Greece and Spain (both -9.4%), UK (-7.8%), Slovenia (-6.4%), Cyprus (-6.3%), Lithuania and Romania (both -5.5%), France (-5.2%), Poland (-5.0%), Slovakia (-4.9%), the Netherlands (-4.5%), Portugal (-4.4%), Italy (-3.9%), Belgium (-3.7%), Latvia (-3.4%) and the Czech Republic (-3.3%).

Three countries achieved surpluses: Hungary (+4.3%), Estonia (+1.1%) and Sweden (+0.4%)

Updated at 10.33am BST

10.14am BST

EUROZONE DEBT TOTAL HITS RECORD HIGH

The Eurozone and the European Union's total debt piles both hit new highs last year, new data released by Eurostat shows.

But in happier news, the Eurozone and the EU both ran a much smaller deficit in 2011 than in 2010.

Here's the topline:

• Eurozone government debt: €8.22 trillion in 2011, up from €7.833 trillion in 2010

• Eurozone debt/GDP: 87.3% in 2011, up from 85.4% in 2010

• Eurozone deficit: 4.1% of GDP in 2011, down from 6.2% in 2010

• EU government debt: €10.433 trillion in 2011, up from €9.826 trillion

• EU debt/GDP: 82.5% in 2011, up from 80.0% in 2010

• EU deficit: -4.4% of GDP in 2011, down from 6.5% in 2010

The full release can be downloaded from the Eurostat website.

Updated at 10.15am BST

9.57am BST

Merkel-Cameron row puts UK's European position in spotlight

The battle between Angela Merkel and David Cameron over the EU budget (see 8.25am) comes amid growing speculation that the first country to quit the European Union might be Britain.

As Peter Ehrlich of FT Deutschland reminds us this morning, there was chat about a possible Brexit during last week's summit in Brussels:

The Wall Street Journal's Simon Nixon has written about this today, warning that the PM's flip-flopping over Europe leaves him "at the mercy of European events".

Here's a flavour:

In recent public statements, Mr. Cameron has indicated he understands the importance of EU membership and his responsibility to defend it. In 10 Downing St., his advisers are not only discussing whether to hold a referendum but also how to win one, says a senior minister involved in the plans. But the weakness of his political position means he cannot rule out leading a campaign to take the U.K. out of the EU if his renegotiation demands are not met.

That puts him in a perilous situation. His hopes for a successful renegotiation rest largely on the belief that the euro zone's only hope of survival lies in full political union and the mutualization of debts. But this may be a miscalculation: Much of the fiscal and banking union needed to resolve the crisis are already in place and much of what remains to be done can probably be done within existing treaties, as it was with the fiscal pact. Even if Mr. Cameron had a radical agenda, the rest of the EU may see no need to indulge him—particularly if, as last December, no U.K. interests are at stake.

Cameron's misfortune/strategic blunder is to be trapped between two formidable obstacles. On one flank (the right, presumably) the Conservative Party's eurosceptics. On the other, a European establishment which is more concerned with saving the single currency than helping the Brits backpedal.

Updated at 9.59am BST

9.34am BST

Talk of snap elections in Greece

Political developments in Greece this morning, where an MP has been slung out out the ruling coalition.

Nikos Stavrogiannis was expelled from New Democracy's parliamentary group after he declared on Sunday that he might not support the country's new austerity programme when it comes before parliament.

Stavrogiannis said the measure being imposed by the Troika are “unfair” and “ineffective”. The intervention prompted Antonis Samaras to throw him out of ND. This still leaves Samaras with a solid majority in parliament.

However, there is also chatter that another general electioncould be needed. The leader of the far-right Independent Greeks party, Panos Kammenos, has suggested that his MPs and those of the left-wing SYRIZA party should resign on masse - ahead of a vote on austerity.

Kammenos said (via Kathimerini):

We will fight this battle in and outside Parliament. But we can stop the measures as well as the country's and the Greek people's surrender, by triggering elections.

Updated at 9.41am BST

8.59am BST

Europe's woes hit Japan

A bleak set of Japanese export numbers have given further proof this morning that the eurozone crisis is hitting the global economy,

Japan's trade deficit widened to 558.6bn yen (or £4.5bn) in September as exports plunged by 10.3%.

Much of the damage was caused by a drop in demand for Japanese manufactured goods from Europe, with European exports plummeting by 26% (other factors included the territorial row with China, and the impact of the strong yen on all exports).

More here.

8.52am BST

Q&A on the Irish banking problem

This article on FT Alphaville is a great explanation of Ireland's banking debt problem: Q&A: Irish promises and promissory notes.

(It's seven months old, but Ireland has made little headway in its pursuit of a better deal since March, so still very relevant)

Speaking of the FT, its Brussels bureau chief Peter Spiegel is somewhat baffled by Merkel's apparent change of heart over Ireland:

8.47am BST

Ministers welcome German support

Irish politicians have hit the airwaves to welcome Angela Merkel's show of support:

8.43am BST

Irish media celebrate victory over bank deal

The Irish media are celebrating the joint statement issued last night by Ireland and Germany over the Irish banking problem (see 8.12am)

It's front-page news on several Irish newspapers, as these tweets from Chris Donoghue, presenter on Ireland's Newstalk Breakfast, show:

The Irish Independent argues that Kenny has proved that he has a special bond with Merkel -- a valuable commodity.

Ireland is likely to be the first eurozone country to escape its bailout (despite the burden of carrying its banking bailout). That, Dublin insiders believe, gives it an advantage.

Ireland's ability to be the first troubled eurozone country to come out of a bailout is also seen as an advantage in negotiations.

On government source said told the Irish Independent:

Ireland can be the success story Europe needs. The only realistic prospect of a country getting out of a programme is Ireland....But until Spain settles down, they don't want to do anything that is setting a precedent.

More on Spain shortly....

8.25am BST

Merkel threatens Cameron with summit cancellation

Angela Merkel has also threatened to cancel the next big European Summit unless David Cameron, the UK prime minister, drops his threat to veto the next EU budget.

Tension between the German and British governments are rising, following Friday's EU summit -- where Cameron pledged to block any new deal on the EU budget that did not include a freeze on spending.

Merkel is not amused. The chancellor is now threatening to cancel the entire EC summit scheduled for November if the British insist on taking such as hard line.

The Financial Times reports:

Angela Merkel, Germany’s chancellor, does not believe there is any point in holding the budget summit to agree on a seven-year framework for EU spending if Britain intends to veto any deal, say people close to the negotiations.

Merkel hopes to get Cameron to agree to her compromise of a budget of just 1% of EU GDP (less than the 1.1% of GDP that the Commission is eying up).

Cameron's pledge to block any increase at this time of financial belt-tightening may win him votes at home, but European allies aren't impressed. As one German source told the FT:

We are trying to show the UK that they have in us an honest partner.

Cameron's position, though, is uncompromising -- No Increase In Spending. His government isn't exactly a stranger to u-turns, but he may feel he can't afford to be beaten on this issue (at at time when Britain is pushing to repatriate a raft of powers).

So if Cameron insists on waving his veto, Merkel's threat to veto the entire summit may not be an empty threat. Trouble ahead...

Updated at 8.26am BST

8.12am BST

GERMANY PROMISES TO HELP IRELAND OVER BANK RESCUE

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone financial crisis - and other key events in the world economy.

The fallout from last week's EU summit is dominating the headlines this morning. First up, Angela Merkel has offered Ireland an olive branch, promising last night that the eurozone remains committed to addressing its bank debts.

After a weekend of diplomatic wrangling, Merkel and Taoiseach Enda Kenny issued a joint statement insisting that the EU leaders would not abandon Ireland.

This comes after Merkel appeared to deliver a nasty blow to Dublin last Friday, by saying that legacy bad bank debts will not be covered by the eurozone's new banking supervisor.

That prompted outrage in Ireland, where there is simmering anger that it is paying hefty interest payments on its €68bn banking bailout while Spain (for example) is being offered help recapitalising its own banks.

Here's the statement that was issued last night:

The Taoiseach Enda Kenny and Chancellor Angela Merkel spoke together this afternoon...They discussed the unique circumstances behind Ireland's banking and sovereign debt crisis, and Ireland's plans for a full return to the markets.

In this regard they reaffirmed the commitment from June 29th to task the Eurogroup to examine the situation of the Irish financial sector with a view to further improving the sustainability of the well performing adjustment programme.

They recognise in this context, that Ireland is a special case, and that the Eurogroup will take that into account.

End.

Ireland, as you may know, took its bad bank debts onto the public books -- arguably saving the eurozone from heavy losses but leaving the taxpayer with the cost of repaying €31bn in promissory notes, at a much higher interest rate than a straight bailout.  It feels unfair.

Dubllin is still some way from an actual deal. but this feels like a victory for Kenny -- who had been blasted by opposition leaders for apparently caving into Merkel.

We'll be tracking the reaction to the developments in Ireland today, as well as reporting on all the major economic & financial developments across the eurozone crisis, and beyond....
fields.bodyText: Looks like events are over for the day, so I'm going to shut up shop till the morning. Here's a closing summary of the main developments: • Ireland has won support from the eurozone's two most powerful leaders over its calls for a new deal on its legacy banking debts. French president François Hollande said he believes Irish banks should be retrospectively recapitalised (see 15.08 onwards). The comments came hours after Dublin and Berlin issued a joint statement saying Ireland deserves 'special treatment' (see 8.12am onwards) • Greece has seen political ructions. Finance minister Yiannis Stournaras warned that Athens risks running out of money (see 16.31) while the expulsion of a government MP showed rising tensions over its austerity package (see 12.46) • David Cameron has pledged not to allow the EU budget to rise above inflation. The UK prime minister told parliament he was still prepared to veto a budget deal, despite German concern (see 15.58 onwards) However both sides denied a report that Angela Merkel might cancel next month's EU summit rather than risk Cameron red-carding the budget (see 11.14 for Berlin's comments and 12.19 for the Downing Street briefing). • Eurozone and EU government debts hit a record high. Data for 2011 also showed that the overall budget deficit of the euro area and the EU fell last year, but 17 countries have deficits above 3%. (See 10.14 onwards) See you again tomorrow. Thanks (as ever), and goodnight! Some late news out of Nicosia – Cyprus is planning to contact its Troika of lenders tonight and invite them back to the island for "final negotiations" on its aid deal (that's via Reuters). Europe's stock markets have closed, with the main indices mostly lower. Traders say a disappointing set of financial results from Caterpillar have eaten into confidence. FTSE 100: down 13 points at 5882, - 0.2% German DAX: down 58 points at 7322, -0.79% French CAC: down 22 points at 3481, -0.65% Spanish IBEX: down 36 points at 7877, - 0.46% Italian FTSE MIB: up 4 points at 15866, + 0.03% In the debt markets, the yield on Spanish 10-year government bonds has been creeping higher through the afternoon, now up 14 basis points at 5.521%. That reflects uncertainty over when Spain might end the suspense and apply for a bailout. Having survived the weekend's regional elections (see 13.52), Mariano Rajoy might drag the drama out a little longer.... Over in Athens alarming statements have been made this afternoon by the country's ever-optimistic finance minister. Our correspondent Helena Smith reports: The Greek finance minister Yiannis Stournaras did not mince his words addressing the Greek parliament this afternoon. Stournaras said that If Greece failed to take receipt of its next rescue loans, "people would go hungry," he said, adding: The cost for the country will be boundless if we don't get the €31.5bn installment... If we don't get the loan people will go hungry. Stournaras also asked, rhetorically, if MPs think "the Europeans are bluffing" over their demands for new cuts, adding: Time is running out. If we want to get the installment before state funds at our disposal are exhausted we must move very quickly. Back to Westminster, where David Cameron has repeated that he will not accept a real-terms increase in the EU budget when leaders meet next month. The PM said: I'm happy to talk, but not happy to spend a lot of money. Cameron added that there is no need to reach a deal on the EU budget in November. However long the issue rumbles on, though, his position won't change.... Cameron also agreed that eurozone banking union will lead towards full political and fiscal union in time, as German taxpayers helping Greek banks or French taxpayers supporting Spanish ones are "deeply political issues". News from Helsinki -- Finnish prime minister Jyrki Katainen was unhurt after a man approached him with a knife on Monday. According to Finland's Helsingin Sanomat newspaper, the man was taken into custody in handcuffs after getting within "a few feet" of Katainen. There are no reports of injuries. Katainen was campaigning in Turku, in Western Finland. The full story can be seen on Helsingin Sanomat's website (in Finnish). David Cameron was just asked whether he supports the decision to award the Nobe Peace Prize to the European Union. In response, the UK PM said There is a case that the institutions which were put into place after the second world war, and I'd include NATO as well as the European Union, have helped us to settle differences round table and not on the battlefields of Flanders. Cameron also confirmed that he won't be showing up in Oslo to collect the prize, and seemed disappointed that the idea of 27 young people acting as Prize-bearers (which he had argued for) had not found favour. One of David Cameron's own MPs, Douglas Carswell, has blasted the government for agreeing Europe's move towards banking union at last week's summit. Over in parliament, David Cameron is updating MPs on the events at last week' EU council summit. Cameron reiterated that he wants some powers repatriated from Brussels, but does not want the UK to quit the European Union. I don't support the Status Quo, but nor do I believe exit is the answer. Cameron also confirmed that he wants the next EU budget to be capped with an inflation-only increase We need to maximise our leverage on that specific issue Several MPs have asked about the plans for a eurozone banking union, with Conservative MP Bernard Jenkins claiming it is the "worst of all possible worlds" for the UK. Cameron disagrees, explaining: The proposals for banking union need to be agreed by unanimity - that is an important safeguard for Britain. But it would not be in Britain's interest to stop the eurozone putting into place something that is necessary for its future. Cameron added that banking union is needed to bring down Spanish and Italian bond yields. Francois Hollande went on to tell the press conference in Paris that he would support a "retroactive recapitalisation" of Irish banks. And here's the key quote from Hollande: I said Ireland was a special case and should be treated as such. Hollande also said that France "will be supportive" if Spain applies for a bailout. The argument for retrospectively putting new capital into Irish banks is that its bailout came before Europe had agreed its new bailout mechanisms - so Ireland arguably got an unfair deal. Tony Connelly of RTE is in Paris, and reports: Irish Taoiseach Enda Kenny has arrived in Paris for his meeting with president Francois Hollande (see 10.45am for more details) And Hollande has been quick to offer Kenny his support, saying that he agrees that Ireland is a special case when it comes to dealing with legacy of its bad banking debts. More to follow... The pound hit another four-month low against the euro today, after dropping around 0.3 of a eurocent to €1.2266. Sterling has been on a steady slide against the euro since late July, when it came close to hitting €1.2900. It began falling after Mario Draghi, ECB president, made his famous speech that 'the euro was irreversible'. Christopher Vecchio, currency analyst at DailyFX, said the euro had been boosted today by the Spanish elections: The election results mean that Spain will not see Prime Minister Rajoy leave office anytime soon. This means that Spain’s future in the Euro is secure (at least the near-term horizon is less uncertain, if only marginally). Mariano Rajoy should seize the moment and apply for financial aid immediately now that regional elections are over, argues a research body with close links to Spain's business leaders. Jose Luis Feito, chairman of Instituto de Estudios Economicos, said that Rajoy's victory in Galicia (see 13.52) should be the catalyst for a bailout request. Feito said (via Bloomberg): Spain should accept conditions set by the European Central Bank and other European authorities and the sooner the better... It’s very difficult to impose substantial cuts in public services that hit living standards, but the longer we wait, the more difficult and drastic it’ll be. Last weekend's election results may have bought Rajoy some time. However there are more elections due in a few weeks, which could bolster political parties seeking independence. As Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research points out: The next bid regional election takes place on November 25th in Catalonia where various parties are pushing for more autonomy or even independence. Think of it like Scotland but with a much better football team… He may have a point... In the City, a calm morning of trading has left the main indices little changed - with the FTSE 100 down just 3 points at 5892, and the German DAX 0.3% lower at 7358. No major drama in the debt markets either, with Spain's 10-year bond yields creeping a little higher to 5.43% this morning. That follows two Spanish regional elections last weekend, which were seen as a possible vote of confidence in the country's austerity prrogramme. The governing People's Party won in Galicia, home state of Mariano Rajoy, Spain's prime minister. However there was also a surge of support for pro-independence candidates in the Basque region, as reported here: Pro-independence parties win Basque country elections in Spain. In short, the election results seen unlikely to trigger the much-awaited aid request from Madrid. As Rebecca O'Keeffe, Head of Investment at Interactive Investor, comments: Rajoy enjoyed a solid victory in regional elections in Galicia, offering support for his current austerity policies, and giving him time to decide when to request a bailout from the EU. This morning's data on eurozone government debt (see 10.14am onwards) also had bad news for Greece, Helena Smith points out. Greece's deficit for 2011 was estimated at 9.4%, up from an earlier forecast of 9.1%. Its debt pile (following March's huge bond swap) was also calculated at €365bn or 170.6% of GDP up from 165.3%. Helena explains: The figures are further proof that all hopes of reaching the debt-to- GDP ratio of 120% by 2020 are conclusively over. Thus the behind-the-scenes battles between the EU and the IMF over how to bring Greece closer to debt sustainability (as our own Ian Traynor wrote back on 12 October) Helena adds: Prime minister Antonis Samaras told reporters in Brussels last week that he had taken a “defensive position” over how the debt load could be made sustainable. Over to Athens again, where our correspondent Helena Smith says the expulsion this morning of a governing New Democracy party MP (see 9.34am) has highlighted the vehemence of the opposition to imposing yet more austerity. With only weeks to go before parliament votes on austerity measures worth €13.5bn – the biggest package of budget cuts since the debt crisis erupted in Athens three years ago – prime minister Antonis Samaras is not taking any chances. Opposition over the cuts is fierce with members of all three parties in his fragile coalition refusing to endorse measures that, once again, will hit pensioners and low-income Greeks hardest. By expelling Nikos Stavrogiannis, one of his own MPs, the conservative leader wanted to send a clear message “that there can be no good or bad politicians who do or don’t support the package,” reported the state-run news network, NET. Samaras's office has also announced that the prime minister will meet his junior coalition partners on Tuesday. Tensions are clearly on the rise, with Syriza leader Alexis Tsipras announcing that “these should be the first measures that are not passed.” and claiming the coalition “is hanging by a thread.” The spending cuts, which will be spread over two years, have to be voted through Athens’ 300-seat House by November 12 when euro zone finance ministers meet to decide whether Greece has qualified for its next cash disbursement – worth €31.5bn. Alarmingly, that's only 4 days before Greece runs out of cash. As on insider told Helena: Once more we are in a race against time if the country is to avoid bankruptcy. However, Syriza has also debunked rumours that the party would trigger a snap poll by getting its deputies to resign en masse from parliament. Helena explains: “Our tactic is to have fresh elections and I would say they are close,” Panos Skourletis told me this morning. “But that doesn’t mean it is a demand for elections here and now,” he said, adding that it was unlikely a new poll would be held before the end of the year. The UK government has told reporters in Westminster that Germany has not threatened to cancel next month's summit (at least, not to them, anyway) My colleague Andrew Sparrow was at the Number 10 briefing, and reports that the government also reiterated its opposition to an above-inflation increase. He writes: We do not see the need for an increase in spending above the rate of inflation," the spokesman said. He would not say what measure of inflation Cameron would use to judge any proposed budget increase. And he said Number 10 had not been told by the Germans that Angela Merkel would cancel next month's EU summit if Cameron was determined to veto the proposed budget, as the Financial Times reports today (paywall). The full briefing is live on Andrew's Politics Live blog. So could the FT have got it wrong? Seems unlikely..... ...and Channel 4's Faisal Islam agrees: The Bundesbank warned this morning that Europe's crisis measures are increasing the risks to eurozone taxpapers. In its monthly report, Germany's central bank once again voiced its concerns over policies such as the European Central Bank's offer of "unlimited bond-buying' for a country which seeks help. Here's the key quote: The more effectively monetary policy supports the financial systems of the crisis countries with its measures, the more risks are transferred to the balance sheet of the euro system and ultimately redistributed among all taxpayers of member countries. The crux of the Bundesbank's argument remains that monetary policy is now being used to stabilise the eurozone, which is really the job of fiscal policy. The Bundesbank also predicted that the German economy could shrink during the last three months of 2012 as demand for exports falls, due to problems across the world economy. It said: While industrial orders from the euro zone have not fallen further after massively dropping in previous quarters, the expansion of demand from other countries has come to a standstill in the wake of a global economic slowdown. Neil Prothero, Eurozone analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit, warns that Britain faces some tough battles in Europe -- the spat over the EU budget is just one problem among many. Prothero writes: The UK's relations with the EU have always been complicated and prickly, but they are now entering uncharted territory as the policy agenda becomes increasingly dominated by politically sensitive issues setting the UK at odds with its EU partners. The first of these is the seven-year framework for the EU budget, covering the period from 2014 to 2020. The European Commission wants the size of the EU budget to be increased, a proposal which is anathema to the British government at a time of fiscal austerity at home. The UK is not the only country opposed to a large increase in the EU budget. But few are likely to fight as hard or as long against an increase as the UK. For his part, the British prime minister, David Cameron, is under enormous pressure from his own largely Eurosceptic Conservative Party to veto any budget deal that is inimical to British interests. Further struggles over banking union and efforts to repatriate key powers will follow, as pressures build on both sides of the Channel. Financial market pressures are forcing euro zone countries to contemplate deeper integration, while domestic political pressures are pushing the UK in the opposite direction. The UK will therefore find itself fighting some lonely battles over the coming months. Our Europe editor Ian Traynor warned a week ago that last week's EU summit would push Britain closer to the exits in this article: Europe prepares for another Franco-German tussle in Brussels. EU policymakers may not want to push the UK out, but they won't jump through hoops to keep the country in, either. The German government has denied that it is threatening to cancel December's EU summit unless Britain caves in over the European Union's budget (see 8.25am) Steffen Seibert, Angela Merkel's official spokesman, just told reporters in Berlin that the report (the front page splash of today's Financial Times) was wrong. Seibert said: It is not true. I categorically deny this report. The German government has an interest in the success of this special summit in November and supports European Council President Herman van Rompuy in the goal to get an agreement on the long-term 2014-2020 budget. Seibert also tried to calm talk that Britain's future in Europe was at risk, saying the UK is a "very valued member" of the EU. But someone will have to change their position over the EU budget. As things stand, Merkel wants a smaller increase than the European Commission is proposing, while Cameron wants no increase at all... There isn't universal joy in Ireland today over the joint statement released by the Dublin and Berlin governments last night. Henry McDonald, our correspondent in Dublin, reports that there is little rejoining on the opposition benches of the Dail (the Irish parliament) at Angela Merkel's show of support (see 8.12am for the details). Henry writes: Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams says today: What is progress is when we get a write-down, when we get our money back. The Louth TD told RTE's "Good Morning Ireland" radio show that: The Government have borrowed €67bn from the troika - €64bn of that into banks, including some banks which are totally failed. The Taoiseach has yet to say that this debt is unsustainable. Kenny meanwhile is in Paris today where the Taoiseach will meet Francois Hollande and also promote Irish food exports. The Republic exported €650 million euros worth of food to the EU last year. France remains one of Ireland's biggest markets with the French eating more Irish lamb and seafood that other Europeans. The Taoiseach will join 18 Irish food companies and Bord Bia (the state body promoting Irish foodstuffs) at a world food fair in the French capital. Last night's telephone chat with the German Chancellor and today's trip to Paris will be welcome relief for Kenny after he and his government faced a string of torrid headlines at the weekend. Most of the Irish Sundays claimed the Germans had thrown Kenny under a car by indicating there would be no bank debt deal for Ireland from the new European Monetary System. Over the last 24 hours however the tone of Dublin newspaper coverage has started to change with the Irish Independent reported today that "Merkel rides to Enda's aid..." HMcD (check out 8.43am for pictures of two Irish front pages). The government debt figures released by Eurostat this morning (see 10.14) also show that 17 of the 25 members of the EU have deficits above 3% (the maximum level 'permitted' under EU laws). They are: • Ireland (-13.4%), Greece and Spain (both -9.4%), UK (-7.8%), Slovenia (-6.4%), Cyprus (-6.3%), Lithuania and Romania (both -5.5%), France (-5.2%), Poland (-5.0%), Slovakia (-4.9%), the Netherlands (-4.5%), Portugal (-4.4%), Italy (-3.9%), Belgium (-3.7%), Latvia (-3.4%) and the Czech Republic (-3.3%). Three countries achieved surpluses: Hungary (+4.3%), Estonia (+1.1%) and Sweden (+0.4%) The Eurozone and the European Union's total debt piles both hit new highs last year, new data released by Eurostat shows. But in happier news, the Eurozone and the EU both ran a much smaller deficit in 2011 than in 2010. Here's the topline: • Eurozone government debt: €8.22 trillion in 2011, up from €7.833 trillion in 2010 • Eurozone debt/GDP: 87.3% in 2011, up from 85.4% in 2010 • Eurozone deficit: 4.1% of GDP in 2011, down from 6.2% in 2010 • EU government debt: €10.433 trillion in 2011, up from €9.826 trillion • EU debt/GDP: 82.5% in 2011, up from 80.0% in 2010 • EU deficit: -4.4% of GDP in 2011, down from 6.5% in 2010 The full release can be downloaded from the Eurostat website. The battle between Angela Merkel and David Cameron over the EU budget (see 8.25am) comes amid growing speculation that the first country to quit the European Union might be Britain. As Peter Ehrlich of FT Deutschland reminds us this morning, there was chat about a possible Brexit during last week's summit in Brussels: The Wall Street Journal's Simon Nixon has written about this today, warning that the PM's flip-flopping over Europe leaves him "at the mercy of European events". Here's a flavour: In recent public statements, Mr. Cameron has indicated he understands the importance of EU membership and his responsibility to defend it. In 10 Downing St., his advisers are not only discussing whether to hold a referendum but also how to win one, says a senior minister involved in the plans. But the weakness of his political position means he cannot rule out leading a campaign to take the U.K. out of the EU if his renegotiation demands are not met. That puts him in a perilous situation. His hopes for a successful renegotiation rest largely on the belief that the euro zone's only hope of survival lies in full political union and the mutualization of debts. But this may be a miscalculation: Much of the fiscal and banking union needed to resolve the crisis are already in place and much of what remains to be done can probably be done within existing treaties, as it was with the fiscal pact. Even if Mr. Cameron had a radical agenda, the rest of the EU may see no need to indulge him—particularly if, as last December, no U.K. interests are at stake. Cameron's misfortune/strategic blunder is to be trapped between two formidable obstacles. On one flank (the right, presumably) the Conservative Party's eurosceptics. On the other, a European establishment which is more concerned with saving the single currency than helping the Brits backpedal. Political developments in Greece this morning, where an MP has been slung out out the ruling coalition. Nikos Stavrogiannis was expelled from New Democracy's parliamentary group after he declared on Sunday that he might not support the country's new austerity programme when it comes before parliament. Stavrogiannis said the measure being imposed by the Troika are “unfair” and “ineffective”. The intervention prompted Antonis Samaras to throw him out of ND. This still leaves Samaras with a solid majority in parliament. However, there is also chatter that another general electioncould be needed. The leader of the far-right Independent Greeks party, Panos Kammenos, has suggested that his MPs and those of the left-wing SYRIZA party should resign on masse - ahead of a vote on austerity. Kammenos said (via Kathimerini): We will fight this battle in and outside Parliament. But we can stop the measures as well as the country's and the Greek people's surrender, by triggering elections. A bleak set of Japanese export numbers have given further proof this morning that the eurozone crisis is hitting the global economy, Japan's trade deficit widened to 558.6bn yen (or £4.5bn) in September as exports plunged by 10.3%. Much of the damage was caused by a drop in demand for Japanese manufactured goods from Europe, with European exports plummeting by 26% (other factors included the territorial row with China, and the impact of the strong yen on all exports). More here. This article on FT Alphaville is a great explanation of Ireland's banking debt problem: Q&A: Irish promises and promissory notes. (It's seven months old, but Ireland has made little headway in its pursuit of a better deal since March, so still very relevant) Speaking of the FT, its Brussels bureau chief Peter Spiegel is somewhat baffled by Merkel's apparent change of heart over Ireland: Irish politicians have hit the airwaves to welcome Angela Merkel's show of support: The Irish media are celebrating the joint statement issued last night by Ireland and Germany over the Irish banking problem (see 8.12am) It's front-page news on several Irish newspapers, as these tweets from Chris Donoghue, presenter on Ireland's Newstalk Breakfast, show: The Irish Independent argues that Kenny has proved that he has a special bond with Merkel -- a valuable commodity. Ireland is likely to be the first eurozone country to escape its bailout (despite the burden of carrying its banking bailout). That, Dublin insiders believe, gives it an advantage. Ireland's ability to be the first troubled eurozone country to come out of a bailout is also seen as an advantage in negotiations. On government source said told the Irish Independent: Ireland can be the success story Europe needs. The only realistic prospect of a country getting out of a programme is Ireland....But until Spain settles down, they don't want to do anything that is setting a precedent. More on Spain shortly.... Angela Merkel has also threatened to cancel the next big European Summit unless David Cameron, the UK prime minister, drops his threat to veto the next EU budget. Tension between the German and British governments are rising, following Friday's EU summit -- where Cameron pledged to block any new deal on the EU budget that did not include a freeze on spending. Merkel is not amused. The chancellor is now threatening to cancel the entire EC summit scheduled for November if the British insist on taking such as hard line. The Financial Times reports: Angela Merkel, Germany’s chancellor, does not believe there is any point in holding the budget summit to agree on a seven-year framework for EU spending if Britain intends to veto any deal, say people close to the negotiations. Merkel hopes to get Cameron to agree to her compromise of a budget of just 1% of EU GDP (less than the 1.1% of GDP that the Commission is eying up). Cameron's pledge to block any increase at this time of financial belt-tightening may win him votes at home, but European allies aren't impressed. As one German source told the FT: We are trying to show the UK that they have in us an honest partner. Cameron's position, though, is uncompromising -- No Increase In Spending. His government isn't exactly a stranger to u-turns, but he may feel he can't afford to be beaten on this issue (at at time when Britain is pushing to repatriate a raft of powers). So if Cameron insists on waving his veto, Merkel's threat to veto the entire summit may not be an empty threat. Trouble ahead... Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone financial crisis - and other key events in the world economy. The fallout from last week's EU summit is dominating the headlines this morning. First up, Angela Merkel has offered Ireland an olive branch, promising last night that the eurozone remains committed to addressing its bank debts. After a weekend of diplomatic wrangling, Merkel and Taoiseach Enda Kenny issued a joint statement insisting that the EU leaders would not abandon Ireland. This comes after Merkel appeared to deliver a nasty blow to Dublin last Friday, by saying that legacy bad bank debts will not be covered by the eurozone's new banking supervisor. That prompted outrage in Ireland, where there is simmering anger that it is paying hefty interest payments on its €68bn banking bailout while Spain (for example) is being offered help recapitalising its own banks. Here's the statement that was issued last night: The Taoiseach Enda Kenny and Chancellor Angela Merkel spoke together this afternoon...They discussed the unique circumstances behind Ireland's banking and sovereign debt crisis, and Ireland's plans for a full return to the markets. In this regard they reaffirmed the commitment from June 29th to task the Eurogroup to examine the situation of the Irish financial sector with a view to further improving the sustainability of the well performing adjustment programme. They recognise in this context, that Ireland is a special case, and that the Eurogroup will take that into account. End. Ireland, as you may know, took its bad bank debts onto the public books -- arguably saving the eurozone from heavy losses but leaving the taxpayer with the cost of repaying €31bn in promissory notes, at a much higher interest rate than a straight bailout. It feels unfair. Dubllin is still some way from an actual deal. but this feels like a victory for Kenny -- who had been blasted by opposition leaders for apparently caving into Merkel. We'll be tracking the reaction to the developments in Ireland today, as well as reporting on all the major economic & financial developments across the eurozone crisis, and beyond....
fields.headline: Eurozone crisis live: Hollande and Merkel both offer Ireland hope
fields.trailText: German chancellor and French president tell Irish taoiseach that Ireland is a 'special case', offering fresh hope of deal on its banking debts

webTitle: Siemens pulls out of loss-making solar power business

fields.standfirst: German industrial group to concentrate renewable energy business on wind and hydroelectric power
fields.body:
German industrial group Siemens is pulling out of its loss-making solar power business, in the latest sign of difficulties in the renewable energy market.

The company said on Monday it would concentrate its renewable energy business on wind and hydroelectric power in a bid to increase productivity. It hopes to sell the unit and is in talks with possible buyers.

Siemens said the solar business had not been as profitable as hoped. "Due to the changed framework conditions, lower growth and strong price pressure in the solar markets, the company's expectations for its solar energy activities have not been met." It said the solar and hydro division generated sales "in the low triple-digit millions" in the year to September and has "roughly 800 employees".

Growing competition from manufacturers in Asia has caused the cost of solar panels to plummet. The industry has also been hit by weaker sales and falling government subsidies. Bruce Jenkyn-Jones, managing director at Impax, an environmental investor with £1.8bn of assets under management, said: "The cost has come down dramatically. There has been an influx of capital. It's very, very competitive; it's only going to be the lowest-cost producers that survive in the middle of this downturn." Various German solar manufacturers have filed for bankruptcy in the past 12 months, including QE Cells and Solar Millennium.

The news comes shortly after General Electric said a poor performance at its wind unit contributed to disappointing third-quarter results. Wind-turbine orders at the industrial conglomerate plunged because a key US subsidy for wind power is scheduled to expire at the end of the year. The chief executive, Jeff Immelt, said GE is assuming "no market" in the US for wind turbines next year without the subsidy. He expects wind revenue to drop 40% next year.

Jenkyn-Jones said: "There's definitely a cyclical element to some of this. In the long term, renewables still look interesting." He said policy changes with regards to renewables posed a major challenge to investors in the industry. "The most important issue for governments is to provide stable frameworks for investors to make sensible decisions."

webTitle: Aggreko falls again but Asos boosted by takeover talk

fields.standfirst: Markets edge lower despite eurozone hopes, with temporary power supply group falling sharply
fields.body:
Aggreko lost its spark again as analysts downgraded after last week's warning from the temporary power supply company. It closed 64p lower at £20.73, the biggest faller in the leading index. HSBC said:

Growth is slowing at Aggreko, but where and by how much and for how long remains unclear. We cut our 2012 and 2013 earnings per share estimates by 6.0% and 7.3%, respectively. Aggreko's rating is now out of kilter with projected capacity growth. We cut to underweight from neutral and our target price from £23.50 to £17.50.

JP Morgan Cazenove also reduced its price target, down from £23.60 to £21.65. Analyst Nicholas de la Grense said:

The standout features of today's results were: a) fleet capex guidance for the first half of 2013, which was below market expectations; b) increased bad debt provisions, which should weigh considerably on the profitability of the international power projects (IPP) business; and c) weaker than expected order intake in IPP. We reduce our IPP growth and margin assumptions, leading to earnings per share cuts of 0.8% in 2012 and 7.0% for 2013.

Overall the markets edged lower for the second day running, with any impetus from the eurozone proving shortlived. A Spanish regional election appeared to strengthen the government's hand in its attempt to avoid a bailout for as long as possible, while Germany support for Ireland was also taken positively. But further disappointing US corporate news, including worse than expected figures from Caterpillar, proved a dominant factor, while a drop in Japanese exports also rekindled worries about a global economic slowdown. So the FTSE 100 finished 13.24 points lower at 5882.91.

Later in the week come a number of key events which are likely to influence the market, including UK and US GDP figures and the latest meeting of the US Federal Reserve.

Shire suffered some profit taking ahead of its latest figures due on Thursday. Its shares lost 33p to £18.22 but in a buy note Deutsche Bank said:

Given the setbacks this year and the over-hang of patent litigation, sentiment has been fragile on the shares. webTitle: Banking regulator Andrew Bailey says 'buck stops here'

fields.standfirst: Banking and insurance regulator outlines more judgment-based, intrusive approach for new Prudential Regulation Authority
fields.body:
Andrew Bailey, the chief regulator of banks and insurance companies, has told his staff that the buck stops with him in the supervision of firms.

Laying out his plans for the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) before a City audience, Bailey admitted that the new regulator being spun out of the Financial Services Authority next year could never stop all banks collapsing.

With the regulator adopting a more judgment-based, intrusive approach to regulation, Bailey said he wants his staff to focus on key issues rather than a wide range of potential problems, as in the past.

Attempting to demonstrate that he will take personal responsibility for the way the PRA regulates 300 banks, he said: "If I emphasise three things we should focus on in a firm and, as I occasionally get asked by supervisors, what if it is the fourth thing that blows the firm up. Well I've made that judgment. It may not be the right judgment in retrospect, but it is the one that I've made."

On secondment from the Bank of England, Bailey is currently acting head of the regulator following the resignation of Hector Sants, although he is expected to be formally appointed to the role.

Documents published alongside the presentation to City professionals showed that the new regulator has backed down from its proposals to tell banks how they are ranked on its new measurement of financial strength, for fear that it could cause them to collapse.

Last year, the FSA unveiled a five-stage assessment, the proactive intervention framework (PIF) – with firms ranked at number one regarded as facing a "low risk" to their viability, and five meaning "winding-up under way". At the time the FSA said that banks will know how they are ranked and did not rule out publishing those rankings.

The latest documents reveal that firms will not be told their rankings, as European rules may require them to inform their shareholders through stock exchange announcements about where they stand. The PRA, however, intends to publish the number of firms it has categorised in each of the five rankings.

"The PRA would prefer to disclose PIF stages to regulated firms as a means of summarising the PRA's overall judgment on safety and soundness. In view of the current disclosure obligations in European legislation, however, the Bank and the FSA have decided not to do so, given the risk that in some cases the firm may be under a legal obligation to disclose its PIF stage publicly," the documents said.

"The PRA will engage with HM Treasury to discuss whether it would be appropriate to pursue changes to relevant European legislation to support disclosure of such supervisory judgments to the firms but not to the market generally."

Bailey told the audience that his goal was for the "public to put their trust in a safe and stable banking system".

In an interview with the Financial Times, Bailey, a long-standing Bank of England employee, recalled a meeting with the treasurer of Royal Bank of Scotland during the 2008 banking crisis.

"The treasurer, John Cummins, came in and I thought he was going to have a heart attack … and he looked at me and said I need £25bn today, can you do it? I said, Yes, I can do that," Bailey said. He was confident he could because he had also been lending cash, privately, to HBOS.

The PRA is to be set up as a subsidiary inside the Bank of England in April.

webTitle: Bad times continue for Vijay Mallya's Kingfisher Airlines

fields.standfirst: Airline executives have reportedly offered staff three of seven months' pay they are owed in bid to get planes flying again
fields.body:
Executives from troubled Kingfisher Airlines, run by the Indian tycoon Vijay Mallya, have met employees to try to thrash out a deal over the seven months of pay they are owed as a first step to getting planes airborne again.

Controlled by the flamboyant Mallya – the 56-year-old self-styled "King of Good Times" – Kingfisher's fleet has been grounded since the start of the month when a staff protest turned violent.

Its licence was suspended on Saturday after it failed to address the Indian regulator's concerns about its operations, forcing the debt-laden carrier to stop taking bookings.

According to local press reports, the company's 6,500 staff were offered one month's pay immediately, another after three working days and a third after the major festival of Diwali in the first week of November.

Kingfisher refused to comment on Monday's meeting, which was described as "inconclusive" in the local media.

Launched in 2005, Kingfisher Airlines was intended to break the mould of Indian air travel by being glamorous, good-looking, efficient and fun.

Mallya featured in the carrier's in-flight videos, welcoming passengers and boasting in a characteristic plummy drawl of "personally picking" cabin staff and instructing them to treat passengers "as if you were a guest in my own home".

Mallya, who inherited the United Breweries conglomerate from his father, epitomised the new breed of Indian businessman: confident, exuberant, exhibitionist and extremely wealthy. He lives in a vast seaside palace in Goa and sits in parliament as an independent senator.

The troubles of Kingfisher have contributed to a broader realisation in India that years of explosive economic growth are coming to an end.

Recent forecasts have put growth in GDP for this year at between 5% and 6%, dropping from 7% last year, and having hit 9.5% in 2010.

There has been much local criticism of Mallya. The Times of India newspaper accused the tycoon of leaving his employees "in the lurch" as the airline ran into problems.

The launch of a promotional video covering the search for models for the Kingfisher annual calendar by the tycoon's son also provoked an angry response.

The airline has never made a profit since being established in 2003 and owes more than £1bn. It will only have its licence reinstated if it provides a plan that satisfies the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA).

A complete cancellation of the licence was unlikely, said a government source, who declined to be named.

The suspension signalled the regulator's lack of patience with Kingfisher after months of cancelled flights and staff walkouts, and marked a rare instance of the government taking a tough stance with a high-profile company.

"The actual position is not changed because of this order," Kingfisher said in a statement this weekend. "We have, in any case, always maintained that once the issues with the employees are resolved, we will first present our resumption plan to DGCA for review, before resuming operations."

Indian passengers have already been hit by price hikes for domestic travel of up to 50%. Though demand remains high, cut-throat competition and high fuel prices have caused problems for many Indian carriers with only one posting a profit.

Analysts have said Kingfisher needs an infusion of at least $1bn (£625m) to stay afloat. Many of its debts are to public institutions such as the State Bank of India.

A recent move by the government to allow greater investment in domestic airlines from overseas has come too late to help the company, analysts said.

Later this week Mallya's Formula One team, Sahara Force India, will race in the country's second grand prix. The tycoon and Dutch businessman Michiel Mol bought the Spyker F1 team for €90m (£75m) in 2007.

webTitle: BP to sell stake in Russian joint venture TNK-BP to Rosneft

fields.standfirst: Deal will eventually see the UK-based oil group receive $12.3bn in cash plus an 18.5% stake in Kremlin-controlled Rosneft
fields.body:
BP is to sell its 50% stake in the Russian oil group TNK-BP to the Kremlin-controlled Rosneft in a deal worth about $27bn (£17bn) to the British company, both parties announced on Monday.

The transaction, which will eventually see the UK-based group receive $12.3bn in cash plus an 18.5% stake in Rosneft, was unveiled as the Russian oil major announced a separate deal to acquire the other half of TNK-BP for the slightly higher price of $28bn from its owner, AAR.

BP chief executive, Bob Dudley, said: "BP intends to be a long-term investor in Rosneft – an investment which I believe will deliver value for our shareholders over the next decade and beyond."

Dudley did not comment on the price and the company declined to explain why AAR appeared to be receiving more for its 50%. However, BP retains the prospect of working on potentially profitable projects with the state-controlled company such as in the Arctic.

The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, said: "This is a good big deal which is important not only for Russia's energy sector but for the entire Russian economy."

Igor Sechin, president and chairman of the management board of Rosneft and a former spy who flew to London last week to take control of the long-running negotiations, said: "I strongly believe that we would benefit from BP's experience and its track record of implementing best international practices in Russia. I am especially pleased that BP has chosen to remain as one of the largest foreign investors in the Russian economy recognising the potential of both Rosneft and the Russian oil and gas sector."

The deal finally gives BP an exit from a venture which has provided a series of difficulties, notably when Dudley was forced to flee Russia in 2008 when he was head of the TNK-BP after threats to his safety. AAR then scuppered BP's hopes of an Arctic tie-up with Rosneft.

However, TNK-BP has also being seen as a huge commercial success for BP. In return for its $8bn investment, the British group has taken out $19bn in dividends – although the frequent rows between the joint venture partners have resulted in those payments being blocked.

As a result of the constant tension between each side of TNK-BP, a deal had long been expected by the oil industry and Dudley had already told his board that he backed Rosneft's cash and share offer for the TNK-BP stake.

The windfall will eventually allow him to hand out billions of pounds to BP shareholders. The company said: "BP intends to retain the shares resulting from the proposed transaction and will evaluate how the cash proceeds will be utilised. At minimum, BP's intention is to offset any dilution to earnings per share as a result of the sale of its interest in TNK-BP as well as continue with its progressive dividend policy."

The agreement to sell BP's 50% stake in TNK-BP to Rosneft, which still has to be signed off by the Russian government, is scheduled to be conducted in two stages: Rosneft will pay BP $17.1bn in cash plus shares in Rosneft, representing 12.84% of the company; then BP will use $4.8bn of that cash windfall to buy a further 5.66% stake in Rosneft from the Russian government. The second deal values Rosneft shares, which were trading at $7.13 last week, at $8 a share.

The net result will be that BP will hold 19.75% of Rosneft shares, including its existing stake of 1.25%, as well as receiving $12.3bn in cash, while the Kremlin's stake – which totalled 86% through two vehicles – will fall to 70%.

There has been speculation the Kremlin will reduce its stake in Rosneft to as low as 50% plus one share. Igor Shuvalov, Russia's deputy prime minister, has said the government would consider further privatisation in an attempt to soothe any concerns among BP investors about the influence of the Kremlin over such a crucial part of the UK oil firm, whose share price is yet to recover from the Deepwater Horizon disaster in the US in April 2010. BP gets a quarter of its production from the existing Russian venture.

The TNK-BP announcement was greeted tentatively by the City, with BP's shares effectively remaining steady.

Stuart Joyner, an analyst at Investec, wrote in a note to clients: "The deal will be viewed positively as it halves exposure to Russia whilst upgrading BP's partnership and reviving hopes of an Arctic entry.

"In accordance with the heads of terms, BP and Rosneft have an exclusivity period of 90 days to negotiate fully termed sale and purchase agreements. After signing definitive agreements, completion would be subject to governmental, regulatory and antitrust approvals, and is currently anticipated to occur during the first half of 2013."
